intro: Carex inops, commonly known as the sparse sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Cyperaceae family. It is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets. Native to moist habitats such as wet meadows and marshy areas, it thrives in environments with consistent moisture. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm and has a clumping growth habit. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems, contributing to soil stabilization and providing habitat for various microorganisms.
